newsitem.title: LIBERIA: Liberians vote massively against rule by the gun.
newsitem.headline: Liberians vote massively against rule by the gun.

text.p: Voters jammed polling stations in Liberia on Saturday in what political leaders described as an overwhelming rejection of rule by the gun.
Long lines snaked from polling centres as early as 4.00 A.M. (0400 GMT) as Liberians scrambled to cast votes for the war-scarred nation's first democratic elections for 12 years.
The presidential and parliamentary polls were designed by Liberia's regional peace brokers to wrap up an accord ending seven years of civil war that has devastated the country.

Nearly every family in Liberia has been touched by the war which killed more than 150,000 and displaced half the pre-war population of 2.5 million. Fear of a return to violence by losing candidates remains a source of concern.

However, the top two rated candidates in a field of 12 presidential contenders -- former warlord Charles Taylor and ex-minister and United Nations official Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf -- said voter enthusiasm showed Liberians were against war.
"There is no violence now and there will be no violence after (the elections)," Taylor told reporters after voting in his Congo Town stronghold district of the capital.
"I think the Liberian people are saying to the world that we are ready for democracy ... and that we must put violence behind us and look at the new millennium," he added.
The supremely confident Taylor said he would work with any other winner but quickly ruled out any thought of losing.
His followers say, as leader of the largest militia before disarmament, a Taylor presidency would be the best guarantee of peace in Liberia.
"He killed my father but I'll vote him. He started all this and he's going to fix it," said one at a polling station.
However, many local analysts say Taylor could face a coalition of rival warlords -- two of them are running for president -- if Johnson-Sirleaf, 58, forces a runoff ballot.
The charismatic Taylor, 49, looked relaxed as he arrived amid heavy security and was greeted by a party of West African foreign ministers observing the poll.
Johnson-Sirleaf voted at a polling centre inside a building used by African peacekeepers to disarm guerrillas last year.
"I feel great. I think the Liberian people are ready for change, ready for a woman (president)," she told reporters.
"The campaign period was clear indication of the readiness to go on from war to peace," she added.
Liberians were voting almost on the eve of the 150th birthday on July 26 of their country, founded by freed American slaves in 1847 as Africa's first modern republic.
Voters were also electing 26 senators and 64 lower house deputies in the poll based on proportional representation.
Taylor started civil war in 1989 and came close to taking the capital in 1990 and 1992 but was blocked on each occasion by troops of the Nigerian-led ECOMOG peacekeeping force.
The peacekeepers stayed on to disarm fighters and police the elections under peace accords signed by faction leaders.
Witnesses reported heavy but orderly voting across the capital and in outlying districts such as Harbel, where the U.S.-owned Firestone rubber plantation and factory are located.
Former U.S. president Jimmy Carter, the highest-ranking international poll observer, toured polling stations with members of his Carter Center delegation.
"I have never seen so many people waiting in line so early to vote," said Carter, whose centre has monitored elections in locations ranging from Haiti to Ghana.
Polls close at 4.00 P.M. (1600 GMT) with early returns due from Sunday night. Final results should be known by Wednesday night, electoral officials said.
If no candidate polls more than 50 percent, a runoff ballot will be held on August 2, the date set for the inauguration of a new president if a winner emerges from the first round.
